arguments.query: Create an AI agent with Microsoft platform
AI agent creation, Azure AI, conversational AI, machine learning, LLM, Copilot, Cognitive Services, automation
Build, deploy, and integrate AI agents, LLMs, Copilot, conversational bots, Azure AI, Cognitive Services

content.text:
{"results":[{"title":"Create and deploy a custom AI agent","content":"# Create and deploy a custom AI agent
This article describes how to create and deploy a custom AI agent in Microsoft 365 Copilot for Service.
## Prerequisites
1. [Get access to Copilot for Service](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-copilot-service/get-started-access).
2. You need a System Customizer or System Administrator role on the environment where your custom AI agent is created. Learn more in [predefined security roles](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/admin/database-security#predefined-security-roles).
## Create a custom AI agent
You can create a custom AI agent in a few easy steps.
1. Go to the landing page for [Copilot for Service](https://aka.ms/TrySC).
2. A wizard appears, where you can create your custom AI agent. Select **Custom service agent** and then select **Get Started**.
3. Set the name of the custom AI agent you want to create or continue with the predefined name, and then select **Create**.
 The environment defaults to the new Copilot for Service environment, but you can create the custom AI agent in a Copilot for Service trial environment. You're set up with System Customizer privileges in this environment.
 Note
 The custom AI agent can only be created in English language at this time.
4. Set up your connections and sources of knowledge for your custom AI agent.
 Add content sources like websites and knowledge base articles from [customer engagement services](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-copilot-service/content-sources-external), so that your AI agent can respond to real-time questions. These websites serve as a source of generative answers. Learn more in [Manage content Sources](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-copilot-service/content-sources-overview).
5. Select **Create** to create your AI agent.
 The new environment and AI agent are created. This process can take a few minutes. Once created, you land in the **Overview** page with a test chat open.
6. Test the custom AI agent by typing questions in the **Chat**. In the **Test it out** panel, you can ask questions that trigger the generative answers capability. You might receive some types unhelpful responses for questions such as personal questions, questions that require authenticated access to content, or have no source content in the specified URL.
Note
1. Only one custom AI agent can be created per environment.
2. You can only have one custom AI agent per environment.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-copilot-service/get-started-quickstart"},{"title":"Create and deploy an agent with Microsoft 365 Agents SDK","content":"# Create and deploy an agent with Microsoft 365 Agents SDK
## Get started with the SDK
You can get started with the Microsoft 365 Agents SDK in one of three ways:
1. Use the Microsoft 365 Agents Toolkit (recommended) - Available in C#, JavaScript, and Python for Visual Studio and Visual Studio Code, the toolkit provides scaffolding and templates to help you set up your agent project.
2. Clone a sample project - Start with a working example and open it in your preferred IDE.
3. Use the CLI - Generate a new agent using command-line tools.
### Use the Agents Toolkit (recommended)
The Microsoft 365 Agents Toolkit helps you quickly scaffold agent projects using built-in templates for Visual Studio and Visual Studio Code.
The Agents Toolkit includes the following templates:
1. **Echo Agent / Empty Agent** - Start from a minimal baseline and add your own AI, orchestration, and knowledge sources.
2. **Weather Agent** - Integrate Azure Foundry or OpenAI AI services with orchestration tools like Semantic Kernel or LangChain already configured for you.
You can run and test your agent locally by using the agents playground. For more information, see the following articles:
1. [Create a new agent using Visual Studio (C#)](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/agents-sdk/create-new-toolkit-project-vs)
2. [Create a new agent using Visual Studio Code (JavaScript & Python coming soon)](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/agents-sdk/create-new-toolkit-project-vsc)
### Clone a sample project or use the CLI
If you prefer not to use the Agents Toolkit, you can clone a sample in GitHub or use the CLI.
To get started, see the [Agents SDK quickstart](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/agents-sdk/create-test-basic-agent?tabs=csharp).
## Deploy your agent
Deploying your agent is dependent on your choice of platform. For example, to deploy to Azure, you can follow the steps in [Deploy your agent to Azure manually](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/agents-sdk/deploy-azure-bot-service-manually). For other platforms, see the platform documentation for deploying web apps.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-365-copilot/extensibility/create-deploy-agents-sdk#get-started-with-the-sdk"},{"title":"Azure AI Foundry Agents (programming-language-csharp)","content":"# Azure AI Foundry Agents (programming-language-csharp)
## Using the agent
The agent is a standard `AIAgent` and supports all standard `AIAgent` operations.
For more information on how to run and interact with agents, see the [Agent getting started tutorials](https://learn.microsoft.com/agent-framework/get-started/your-first-agent).
# Azure AI Foundry Agents (programming-language-python)
Microsoft Agent Framework supports creating agents that use the [Azure AI Foundry Agents](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/overview) service. You can create persistent service-based agent instances with service-managed chat history.
## Configuration
### Environment Variables
Before using Azure AI Foundry Agents, you need to set up these environment variables:
```bash
export AZURE_AI_PROJECT_ENDPOINT="https://<your-project>.services.ai.azure.com/api/projects/<project-id>"
export AZURE_AI_MODEL_DEPLOYMENT_NAME="gpt-4o-mini"
```
Alternatively, you can provide these values directly in your code.
### Installation
Add the Agent Framework Azure AI package to your project:
```bash
pip install agent-framework-azure-ai --pre
```
## Getting Started
### Authentication
Azure AI Foundry Agents use Azure credentials for authentication. The simplest approach is to use `AzureCliCredential` after running `az login`:
```python
from azure.identity.aio import AzureCliCredential

async with AzureCliCredential() as credential:
    # Use credential with Azure AI agent client
```
## Create Azure AI Foundry Agents
### Basic Agent Creation
The simplest way to create an agent is using the `AzureAIAgentClient` with environment variables:
```python
import asyncio
from agent_framework.azure import AzureAIAgentClient
from azure.identity.aio import AzureCliCredential

async def main():
    async with (
        AzureCliCredential() as credential,
        AzureAIAgentClient(async_credential=credential).as_agent(
            name="HelperAgent",
            instructions="You are a helpful assistant."
        ) as agent,
    ):
        result = await agent.run("Hello!")
        print(result.text)

asyncio.run(main())
```
### Explicit Configuration
You can also provide configuration explicitly instead of using environment variables:","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/agent-framework/agents/providers/azure-ai-foundry#using-the-agent"},{"title":"Work with environments in Service","content":"# Work with environments in Service
## Create an agent in an existing environment
To create an AI agent in an existing environment, select the environment in the [copilot creation window](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-copilot-service/get-started-quickstart).
### Create an agent in an environment where you don't have access
To create an AI agent in an environment where you don't have access, you must be a system administrator or contact your system administrator. You then need to complete the following steps:
1. Create an AI agent in the environment (this step installs the necessary Service components).
2. Assign the security role of "System Customizer" to yourself in the environment. Learn more in [Create users and assign security roles](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/admin/create-users-assign-online-security-roles#assign-a-security-role-to-a-user) in the Power Platform admin documentation.
You can then return to the Service portal in Microsoft 365 Copilot and create an AI agent in the environment.
Learn more in [environments overview](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/admin/environments-overview) and [configure environment security](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/admin/database-security)
## Trial environments
When you try Service in Microsoft 365 Copilot, you can create a trial environment that expires after 30 days. When the environment expires, all AI agents in the environment are deleted. The data associated with the AI agent, including any flows and resources you have been using, is lost.
If you created your own environment and selected **Trial** as the environment type, you receive email notices shortly before it expires. If you created AI agents in a trial environment, you are notified in the Service portal two weeks before they expire.
Note
There's a difference between an expiring *environment* and an expiring *license*. If your license is expiring, you can extend it without losing any data. Learn more in [Get access to Service in Microsoft 365 Copilot](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-copilot-service/get-started-access).
## Converting a trial environment to a production environment
If you use a trial environment and want to retain your Copilot agents longer than 30 days, you must [convert the trial environment to a production environment](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/admin/trial-environments#convert-a-trial-environment-to-production).","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-copilot-service/admin-working-with-environments#create-an-agent-in-an-existing-environment"},{"title":"Azure AI Foundry Agents (programming-language-csharp)","content":"# Azure AI Foundry Agents (programming-language-csharp)
Microsoft Agent Framework supports creating agents that use the [Azure AI Foundry Agents](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/overview) service. You can create persistent service-based agent instances with service-managed chat history.
## Getting Started
Add the required NuGet packages to your project.
```dotnetcli
dotnet add package Azure.Identity
dotnet add package Microsoft.Agents.AI.AzureAI.Persistent --prerelease
```
## Create Azure AI Foundry Agents
As a first step you need to create a client to connect to the Azure AI Foundry Agents service.
```csharp
using System;
using Azure.AI.Agents.Persistent;
using Azure.Identity;
using Microsoft.Agents.AI;

var persistentAgentsClient = new PersistentAgentsClient(
    "https://<myresource>.services.ai.azure.com/api/projects/<myproject>",
    new DefaultAzureCredential());
```
Warning
`DefaultAzureCredential` is convenient for development but requires careful consideration in production. In production, consider using a specific credential (e.g., `ManagedIdentityCredential`) to avoid latency issues, unintended credential probing, and potential security risks from fallback mechanisms.
To use the Azure AI Foundry Agents service, you need create an agent resource in the service. This can be done using either the Azure.AI.Agents.Persistent SDK or using Microsoft Agent Framework helpers.
### Using the Persistent SDK
Create a persistent agent and retrieve it as an `AIAgent` using the `PersistentAgentsClient`.
### Using Agent Framework helpers
You can also create and return an `AIAgent` in one step:
```csharp
AIAgent agent2 = await persistentAgentsClient.CreateAIAgentAsync(
    model: "gpt-4o-mini",
    name: "Joker",
    instructions: "You are good at telling jokes.");
```
## Reusing Azure AI Foundry Agents
You can reuse existing Azure AI Foundry Agents by retrieving them using their IDs.
```csharp
AIAgent agent3 = await persistentAgentsClient.GetAIAgentAsync("<agent-id>");
```
Tip
See the [.NET samples](https://github.com/microsoft/agent-framework/tree/main/dotnet/samples) for complete runnable examples.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/agent-framework/agents/providers/azure-ai-foundry"},{"title":"Discover, create, and onboard an agent","content":"# Discover, create, and onboard an agent
## Create an agent
To create an agent, follow these steps:
1. Select **Request** on the agent template details page.
 [![Request an agent.](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-agent-365/media/onboard/agent-request.png)](media/onboard/agent-request.png#lightbox)
2. Admin approves the request in the Microsoft 365 admin center, activates the template, and assigns licenses and policies. Learn more in [Agent 365 Overview page in the Microsoft 365 admin center](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/manage/agent-365-overview).
3. After activation, select **Create** on the template page.
4. Configure the agent:
4.1. **Agent icon**: The icon that appears for the agent.
4.2. **Name (configurable)**: The name of the agent. Don't use spaces or special characters in the agent name.
4.3. **Agent description**: The description for the agent.
5. Select **Save** to finish.
## Onboard an agent
After you create an agent, the AI agent appears in your organization chart under the creator's supervision. You can interact with the AI agent using Teams chat, channels, and meetings.
Configure more settings in the agent card in Teams or Copilot chat.
Pause or delete agents in Teams or Copilot chat. Tenant admins can also manage agents in the Microsoft 365 admin center.
Resources associated with an agent remain for 30 days after deletion.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-agent-365/onboard#create-an-agent"},{"title":"Step 1: Your First Agent (programming-language-csharp)","content":"# Step 1: Your First Agent (programming-language-csharp)
Create an agent and get a response — in just a few lines of code.
```dotnetcli
dotnet add package Azure.AI.OpenAI --prerelease
dotnet add package Azure.Identity
dotnet add package Microsoft.Agents.AI.OpenAI --prerelease
```
Create the agent:
Run it:
```csharp
Console.WriteLine(await agent.RunAsync("What is the largest city in France?"));
```
Or stream the response:
```csharp
await foreach (var update in agent.RunStreamingAsync("Tell me a one-sentence fun fact."))
{
    Console.Write(update);
}
```
Tip
See the [full sample](https://github.com/microsoft/agent-framework/blob/main/dotnet/samples/01-get-started/01_HelloAgent.cs) for the complete runnable file.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/agent-framework/get-started/your-first-agent"},{"title":"Tutorial: Build an agentic web app in Azure App Service with Microsoft Agent Framework or Foundry Agent Service (.NET)","content":"# Tutorial: Build an agentic web app in Azure App Service with Microsoft Agent Framework or Foundry Agent Service (.NET)
## Create and configure the Microsoft Foundry resource
**Microsoft Agent Framework**
1. In the [Foundry portal](https://ai.azure.com), make sure the top **New Foundry** radio button is set to active and create a project.
2. Deploy a model of your choice (see [Microsoft Foundry Quickstart: Create resources](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/quickstarts/get-started-code?view=foundry&preserve-view=true#create-resources)).
3. From top of the model playground, copy the model name.
4. The easiest way to get the Azure OpenAI endpoint is still from the classic portal. Select the **New Foundry** radio button, then **Azure OpenAI**, and then copy the URL in **Azure OpenAI endpoint** for later.
 ![Screenshot showing how to copy the OpenAI endpoint and the foundry project endpoint in the foundry portal.](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/app-service/media/tutorial-ai-agent-web-app-semantic-kernel-foundry-dotnet/foundry-project-openai-endpoint.png)
**Foundry Agent Service**
1. In the [Foundry portal](https://ai.azure.com), make sure the top **New Foundry** radio button is set to active and create a project.
2. In the home page, copy the **Project endpoint** for later.
3. Select **Start building** > **Create agent** and follow the prompt.
4. In the new agent's playground, create an OpenAPI tool to call your web app by selecting **Tools** > **Add** > **Custom** > **OpenAPI tool** > **Create**. In the **Setup** pane, add an action with the OpenAPI spec tool. Use the OpenAPI schema that you get from the deployed web app and **anonymous** authentication. For detailed steps, see [How to use the OpenAPI spec tool](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/how-to/tools/openapi?view=foundry&preserve-view=true).
 Your application code is already configured to include the server's `url` and `operationId`, which are needed by the agent. For more information, see [Connect to OpenAPI Specification](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/how-to/tools/openapi?view=foundry&preserve-view=true#prerequisites).
5. Be sure to select **Save**.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/app-service/tutorial-ai-agent-web-app-semantic-kernel-foundry-dotnet#create-and-configure-the-microsoft-foundry-resource"},{"title":"Discover, create, and onboard an agent","content":"# Discover, create, and onboard an agent
Important
1. You need to be part of the [Frontier preview program](https://adoption.microsoft.com/copilot/frontier-program/) to get **early access** to Microsoft Agent 365. Frontier connects you directly with Microsoft’s latest AI innovations. Get hands-on with breakthrough features, share your insights with product teams, and help shape the future of AI. Frontier previews are subject to the existing preview terms of your customer agreements. As these features are still in development, their availability and capabilities may change over time.
You discover approved agent templates in your Microsoft 365 tenant. Agent templates are preconfigured templates for AI-powered Agent 365 agents in Microsoft 365. These templates define the agent’s capabilities, identity, and compliance settings. Users can add and configure, also known as *onboard* agents after admin approval to automate tasks and enhance team productivity.
## Prerequisites
1. You need admin approval for your request in the Microsoft 365 admin center before creating an agent.
2. You need a "Microsoft Agent 365 Frontier" subscription enabled by the tenant admins in the Microsoft 365 admin center. This 25-seat subscription allows hiring autonomous agents.
## Discover agent templates
Agent templates are available in the Microsoft 365 Copilot Store under **Agents for your team** or in the **Apps** area in Microsoft Teams. All users in the tenant can find and view agent templates.
[![Available agents in Teams.](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-agent-365/media/onboard/discover-agent-teams.png)](media/onboard/discover-agent-teams.png#lightbox)
Users can select an agent template from the **Agents for your team** category in Teams and the Microsoft 365 Agent store. 
When you select a template, the detail pane shows:
1. Description and skills
2. Developer information
3. Required licenses and policies","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-agent-365/onboard"},{"title":"OpenAI Agents (programming-language-csharp)","content":"# OpenAI Agents (programming-language-csharp)
Microsoft Agent Framework supports three distinct OpenAI client types, each targeting a different API surface with different tool capabilities:
| Client Type | API | Best For| 
|  --- | --- | ---  |
| **Chat Completion** | [Chat Completions API](https://platform.openai.com/docs/api-reference/chat/create) | Simple agents, broad model support |
| **Responses** | [Responses API](https://platform.openai.com/docs/api-reference/responses) | Full-featured agents with hosted tools (code interpreter, file search, web search, hosted MCP) |
| **Assistants** | [Assistants API](https://platform.openai.com/docs/api-reference/assistants) | Server-managed agents with code interpreter and file search |

Tip
For Azure OpenAI equivalents (`AzureOpenAIChatClient`, `AzureOpenAIResponsesClient`, `AzureOpenAIAssistantsClient`), see the [Azure OpenAI provider page](https://learn.microsoft.com/agent-framework/agents/providers/azure-openai). The tool support is identical.
## Getting Started
Add the required NuGet packages to your project.
```dotnetcli
dotnet add package Microsoft.Agents.AI.OpenAI --prerelease
```
## Chat Completion Client
The Chat Completion client provides a straightforward way to create agents using the ChatCompletion API.
```csharp
using Microsoft.Agents.AI;
using OpenAI;

OpenAIClient client = new OpenAIClient("<your_api_key>");
var chatClient = client.GetChatClient("gpt-4o-mini");

AIAgent agent = chatClient.AsAIAgent(
    instructions: "You are good at telling jokes.",
    name: "Joker");

Console.WriteLine(await agent.RunAsync("Tell me a joke about a pirate."));
```
**Supported tools:** Function tools, web search, local MCP tools.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/agent-framework/agents/providers/openai"}]}

results.title: Create and deploy a custom AI agent
results.content:
# Create and deploy a custom AI agent
This article describes how to create and deploy a custom AI agent in Microsoft 365 Copilot for Service.
## Prerequisites
1. [Get access to Copilot for Service](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-copilot-service/get-started-access).
2. You need a System Customizer or System Administrator role on the environment where your custom AI agent is created. Learn more in [predefined security roles](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/admin/database-security#predefined-security-roles).
## Create a custom AI agent
You can create a custom AI agent in a few easy steps.
1. Go to the landing page for [Copilot for Service](https://aka.ms/TrySC).
2. A wizard appears, where you can create your custom AI agent. Select **Custom service agent** and then select **Get Started**.
3. Set the name of the custom AI agent you want to create or continue with the predefined name, and then select **Create**.
 The environment defaults to the new Copilot for Service environment, but you can create the custom AI agent in a Copilot for Service trial environment. You're set up with System Customizer privileges in this environment.
 Note
 The custom AI agent can only be created in English language at this time.
4. Set up your connections and sources of knowledge for your custom AI agent.
 Add content sources like websites and knowledge base articles from [customer engagement services](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-copilot-service/content-sources-external), so that your AI agent can respond to real-time questions. These websites serve as a source of generative answers. Learn more in [Manage content Sources](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-copilot-service/content-sources-overview).
5. Select **Create** to create your AI agent.
 The new environment and AI agent are created. This process can take a few minutes. Once created, you land in the **Overview** page with a test chat open.
6. Test the custom AI agent by typing questions in the **Chat**. In the **Test it out** panel, you can ask questions that trigger the generative answers capability. You might receive some types unhelpful responses for questions such as personal questions, questions that require authenticated access to content, or have no source content in the specified URL.
Note
1. Only one custom AI agent can be created per environment.
2. You can only have one custom AI agent per environment.

results.title: Create and deploy an agent with Microsoft 365 Agents SDK
results.content:
# Create and deploy an agent with Microsoft 365 Agents SDK
## Get started with the SDK
You can get started with the Microsoft 365 Agents SDK in one of three ways:
1. Use the Microsoft 365 Agents Toolkit (recommended) - Available in C#, JavaScript, and Python for Visual Studio and Visual Studio Code, the toolkit provides scaffolding and templates to help you set up your agent project.
2. Clone a sample project - Start with a working example and open it in your preferred IDE.
3. Use the CLI - Generate a new agent using command-line tools.
### Use the Agents Toolkit (recommended)
The Microsoft 365 Agents Toolkit helps you quickly scaffold agent projects using built-in templates for Visual Studio and Visual Studio Code.
The Agents Toolkit includes the following templates:
1. **Echo Agent / Empty Agent** - Start from a minimal baseline and add your own AI, orchestration, and knowledge sources.
2. **Weather Agent** - Integrate Azure Foundry or OpenAI AI services with orchestration tools like Semantic Kernel or LangChain already configured for you.
You can run and test your agent locally by using the agents playground. For more information, see the following articles:
1. [Create a new agent using Visual Studio (C#)](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/agents-sdk/create-new-toolkit-project-vs)
2. [Create a new agent using Visual Studio Code (JavaScript & Python coming soon)](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/agents-sdk/create-new-toolkit-project-vsc)
### Clone a sample project or use the CLI
If you prefer not to use the Agents Toolkit, you can clone a sample in GitHub or use the CLI.
To get started, see the [Agents SDK quickstart](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/agents-sdk/create-test-basic-agent?tabs=csharp).
## Deploy your agent
Deploying your agent is dependent on your choice of platform. For example, to deploy to Azure, you can follow the steps in [Deploy your agent to Azure manually](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/agents-sdk/deploy-azure-bot-service-manually). For other platforms, see the platform documentation for deploying web apps.

results.title: Azure AI Foundry Agents (programming-language-csharp)
results.content:
# Azure AI Foundry Agents (programming-language-csharp)
## Using the agent
The agent is a standard `AIAgent` and supports all standard `AIAgent` operations.
For more information on how to run and interact with agents, see the [Agent getting started tutorials](https://learn.microsoft.com/agent-framework/get-started/your-first-agent).
# Azure AI Foundry Agents (programming-language-python)
Microsoft Agent Framework supports creating agents that use the [Azure AI Foundry Agents](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/overview) service. You can create persistent service-based agent instances with service-managed chat history.
## Configuration
### Environment Variables
Before using Azure AI Foundry Agents, you need to set up these environment variables:
```bash
export AZURE_AI_PROJECT_ENDPOINT="https://<your-project>.services.ai.azure.com/api/projects/<project-id>"
export AZURE_AI_MODEL_DEPLOYMENT_NAME="gpt-4o-mini"
```
Alternatively, you can provide these values directly in your code.
### Installation
Add the Agent Framework Azure AI package to your project:
```bash
pip install agent-framework-azure-ai --pre
```
## Getting Started
### Authentication
Azure AI Foundry Agents use Azure credentials for authentication. The simplest approach is to use `AzureCliCredential` after running `az login`:
```python
from azure.identity.aio import AzureCliCredential

async with AzureCliCredential() as credential:
    # Use credential with Azure AI agent client
```
## Create Azure AI Foundry Agents
### Basic Agent Creation
The simplest way to create an agent is using the `AzureAIAgentClient` with environment variables:
```python
import asyncio
from agent_framework.azure import AzureAIAgentClient
from azure.identity.aio import AzureCliCredential

async def main():
    async with (
        AzureCliCredential() as credential,
        AzureAIAgentClient(async_credential=credential).as_agent(
            name="HelperAgent",
            instructions="You are a helpful assistant."
        ) as agent,
    ):
        result = await agent.run("Hello!")
        print(result.text)

asyncio.run(main())
```
### Explicit Configuration
You can also provide configuration explicitly instead of using environment variables:

results.title: Work with environments in Service
results.content:
# Work with environments in Service
## Create an agent in an existing environment
To create an AI agent in an existing environment, select the environment in the [copilot creation window](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-copilot-service/get-started-quickstart).
### Create an agent in an environment where you don't have access
To create an AI agent in an environment where you don't have access, you must be a system administrator or contact your system administrator. You then need to complete the following steps:
1. Create an AI agent in the environment (this step installs the necessary Service components).
2. Assign the security role of "System Customizer" to yourself in the environment. Learn more in [Create users and assign security roles](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/admin/create-users-assign-online-security-roles#assign-a-security-role-to-a-user) in the Power Platform admin documentation.
You can then return to the Service portal in Microsoft 365 Copilot and create an AI agent in the environment.
Learn more in [environments overview](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/admin/environments-overview) and [configure environment security](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/admin/database-security)
## Trial environments
When you try Service in Microsoft 365 Copilot, you can create a trial environment that expires after 30 days. When the environment expires, all AI agents in the environment are deleted. The data associated with the AI agent, including any flows and resources you have been using, is lost.
If you created your own environment and selected **Trial** as the environment type, you receive email notices shortly before it expires. If you created AI agents in a trial environment, you are notified in the Service portal two weeks before they expire.
Note
There's a difference between an expiring *environment* and an expiring *license*. If your license is expiring, you can extend it without losing any data. Learn more in [Get access to Service in Microsoft 365 Copilot](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-copilot-service/get-started-access).
## Converting a trial environment to a production environment
If you use a trial environment and want to retain your Copilot agents longer than 30 days, you must [convert the trial environment to a production environment](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-platform/admin/trial-environments#convert-a-trial-environment-to-production).

results.title: Azure AI Foundry Agents (programming-language-csharp)
results.content:
# Azure AI Foundry Agents (programming-language-csharp)
Microsoft Agent Framework supports creating agents that use the [Azure AI Foundry Agents](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/overview) service. You can create persistent service-based agent instances with service-managed chat history.
## Getting Started
Add the required NuGet packages to your project.
```dotnetcli
dotnet add package Azure.Identity
dotnet add package Microsoft.Agents.AI.AzureAI.Persistent --prerelease
```
## Create Azure AI Foundry Agents
As a first step you need to create a client to connect to the Azure AI Foundry Agents service.
```csharp
using System;
using Azure.AI.Agents.Persistent;
using Azure.Identity;
using Microsoft.Agents.AI;

var persistentAgentsClient = new PersistentAgentsClient(
    "https://<myresource>.services.ai.azure.com/api/projects/<myproject>",
    new DefaultAzureCredential());
```
Warning
`DefaultAzureCredential` is convenient for development but requires careful consideration in production. In production, consider using a specific credential (e.g., `ManagedIdentityCredential`) to avoid latency issues, unintended credential probing, and potential security risks from fallback mechanisms.
To use the Azure AI Foundry Agents service, you need create an agent resource in the service. This can be done using either the Azure.AI.Agents.Persistent SDK or using Microsoft Agent Framework helpers.
### Using the Persistent SDK
Create a persistent agent and retrieve it as an `AIAgent` using the `PersistentAgentsClient`.
### Using Agent Framework helpers
You can also create and return an `AIAgent` in one step:
```csharp
AIAgent agent2 = await persistentAgentsClient.CreateAIAgentAsync(
    model: "gpt-4o-mini",
    name: "Joker",
    instructions: "You are good at telling jokes.");
```
## Reusing Azure AI Foundry Agents
You can reuse existing Azure AI Foundry Agents by retrieving them using their IDs.
```csharp
AIAgent agent3 = await persistentAgentsClient.GetAIAgentAsync("<agent-id>");
```
Tip
See the [.NET samples](https://github.com/microsoft/agent-framework/tree/main/dotnet/samples) for complete runnable examples.

results.title: Discover, create, and onboard an agent
results.content:
# Discover, create, and onboard an agent
## Create an agent
To create an agent, follow these steps:
1. Select **Request** on the agent template details page.
 [![Request an agent.](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-agent-365/media/onboard/agent-request.png)](media/onboard/agent-request.png#lightbox)
2. Admin approves the request in the Microsoft 365 admin center, activates the template, and assigns licenses and policies. Learn more in [Agent 365 Overview page in the Microsoft 365 admin center](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/admin/manage/agent-365-overview).
3. After activation, select **Create** on the template page.
4. Configure the agent:
4.1. **Agent icon**: The icon that appears for the agent.
4.2. **Name (configurable)**: The name of the agent. Don't use spaces or special characters in the agent name.
4.3. **Agent description**: The description for the agent.
5. Select **Save** to finish.
## Onboard an agent
After you create an agent, the AI agent appears in your organization chart under the creator's supervision. You can interact with the AI agent using Teams chat, channels, and meetings.
Configure more settings in the agent card in Teams or Copilot chat.
Pause or delete agents in Teams or Copilot chat. Tenant admins can also manage agents in the Microsoft 365 admin center.
Resources associated with an agent remain for 30 days after deletion.

results.title: Step 1: Your First Agent (programming-language-csharp)
results.content:
# Step 1: Your First Agent (programming-language-csharp)
Create an agent and get a response — in just a few lines of code.
```dotnetcli
dotnet add package Azure.AI.OpenAI --prerelease
dotnet add package Azure.Identity
dotnet add package Microsoft.Agents.AI.OpenAI --prerelease
```
Create the agent:
Run it:
```csharp
Console.WriteLine(await agent.RunAsync("What is the largest city in France?"));
```
Or stream the response:
```csharp
await foreach (var update in agent.RunStreamingAsync("Tell me a one-sentence fun fact."))
{
    Console.Write(update);
}
```
Tip
See the [full sample](https://github.com/microsoft/agent-framework/blob/main/dotnet/samples/01-get-started/01_HelloAgent.cs) for the complete runnable file.

results.title: Tutorial: Build an agentic web app in Azure App Service with Microsoft Agent Framework or Foundry Agent Service (.NET)
results.content:
# Tutorial: Build an agentic web app in Azure App Service with Microsoft Agent Framework or Foundry Agent Service (.NET)
## Create and configure the Microsoft Foundry resource
**Microsoft Agent Framework**
1. In the [Foundry portal](https://ai.azure.com), make sure the top **New Foundry** radio button is set to active and create a project.
2. Deploy a model of your choice (see [Microsoft Foundry Quickstart: Create resources](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/quickstarts/get-started-code?view=foundry&preserve-view=true#create-resources)).
3. From top of the model playground, copy the model name.
4. The easiest way to get the Azure OpenAI endpoint is still from the classic portal. Select the **New Foundry** radio button, then **Azure OpenAI**, and then copy the URL in **Azure OpenAI endpoint** for later.
 ![Screenshot showing how to copy the OpenAI endpoint and the foundry project endpoint in the foundry portal.](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/app-service/media/tutorial-ai-agent-web-app-semantic-kernel-foundry-dotnet/foundry-project-openai-endpoint.png)
**Foundry Agent Service**
1. In the [Foundry portal](https://ai.azure.com), make sure the top **New Foundry** radio button is set to active and create a project.
2. In the home page, copy the **Project endpoint** for later.
3. Select **Start building** > **Create agent** and follow the prompt.
4. In the new agent's playground, create an OpenAPI tool to call your web app by selecting **Tools** > **Add** > **Custom** > **OpenAPI tool** > **Create**. In the **Setup** pane, add an action with the OpenAPI spec tool. Use the OpenAPI schema that you get from the deployed web app and **anonymous** authentication. For detailed steps, see [How to use the OpenAPI spec tool](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/how-to/tools/openapi?view=foundry&preserve-view=true).
 Your application code is already configured to include the server's `url` and `operationId`, which are needed by the agent. For more information, see [Connect to OpenAPI Specification](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/ai-foundry/agents/how-to/tools/openapi?view=foundry&preserve-view=true#prerequisites).
5. Be sure to select **Save**.

results.title: Discover, create, and onboard an agent
results.content:
# Discover, create, and onboard an agent
Important
1. You need to be part of the [Frontier preview program](https://adoption.microsoft.com/copilot/frontier-program/) to get **early access** to Microsoft Agent 365. Frontier connects you directly with Microsoft’s latest AI innovations. Get hands-on with breakthrough features, share your insights with product teams, and help shape the future of AI. Frontier previews are subject to the existing preview terms of your customer agreements. As these features are still in development, their availability and capabilities may change over time.
You discover approved agent templates in your Microsoft 365 tenant. Agent templates are preconfigured templates for AI-powered Agent 365 agents in Microsoft 365. These templates define the agent’s capabilities, identity, and compliance settings. Users can add and configure, also known as *onboard* agents after admin approval to automate tasks and enhance team productivity.
## Prerequisites
1. You need admin approval for your request in the Microsoft 365 admin center before creating an agent.
2. You need a "Microsoft Agent 365 Frontier" subscription enabled by the tenant admins in the Microsoft 365 admin center. This 25-seat subscription allows hiring autonomous agents.
## Discover agent templates
Agent templates are available in the Microsoft 365 Copilot Store under **Agents for your team** or in the **Apps** area in Microsoft Teams. All users in the tenant can find and view agent templates.
[![Available agents in Teams.](https://learn.microsoft.com/microsoft-agent-365/media/onboard/discover-agent-teams.png)](media/onboard/discover-agent-teams.png#lightbox)
Users can select an agent template from the **Agents for your team** category in Teams and the Microsoft 365 Agent store. 
When you select a template, the detail pane shows:
1. Description and skills
2. Developer information
3. Required licenses and policies

results.title: OpenAI Agents (programming-language-csharp)
results.content:
# OpenAI Agents (programming-language-csharp)
Microsoft Agent Framework supports three distinct OpenAI client types, each targeting a different API surface with different tool capabilities:
| Client Type | API | Best For| 
|  --- | --- | ---  |
| **Chat Completion** | [Chat Completions API](https://platform.openai.com/docs/api-reference/chat/create) | Simple agents, broad model support |
| **Responses** | [Responses API](https://platform.openai.com/docs/api-reference/responses) | Full-featured agents with hosted tools (code interpreter, file search, web search, hosted MCP) |
| **Assistants** | [Assistants API](https://platform.openai.com/docs/api-reference/assistants) | Server-managed agents with code interpreter and file search |

Tip
For Azure OpenAI equivalents (`AzureOpenAIChatClient`, `AzureOpenAIResponsesClient`, `AzureOpenAIAssistantsClient`), see the [Azure OpenAI provider page](https://learn.microsoft.com/agent-framework/agents/providers/azure-openai). The tool support is identical.
## Getting Started
Add the required NuGet packages to your project.
```dotnetcli
dotnet add package Microsoft.Agents.AI.OpenAI --prerelease
```
## Chat Completion Client
The Chat Completion client provides a straightforward way to create agents using the ChatCompletion API.
```csharp
using Microsoft.Agents.AI;
using OpenAI;

OpenAIClient client = new OpenAIClient("<your_api_key>");
var chatClient = client.GetChatClient("gpt-4o-mini");

AIAgent agent = chatClient.AsAIAgent(
    instructions: "You are good at telling jokes.",
    name: "Joker");

Console.WriteLine(await agent.RunAsync("Tell me a joke about a pirate."));
```
**Supported tools:** Function tools, web search, local MCP tools.
